title: 111_s3166
content: The Act titled "Ponzi Scheme Victim's Bill of Rights Act of 2010" addresses the treatment of qualified fraudulent investment losses in individual retirement accounts. The Act "Ponzi Scheme Victim's Bill of Rights Act of 2010" amends the Internal Revenue Code to include special rules for qualified fraudulent investment losses in individual retirement accounts. Beneficiaries of such plans can deduct the loss amount equal to the contributions made by them or their employer. The Act "Ponzi Scheme Victim's Bill of Rights Act of 2010" allows beneficiaries of individual retirement accounts to deduct qualified fraudulent investment losses, up to $1,500,000 or 50% of the excess of assets before and after the loss discovery. The term 'qualified fraudulent investment loss' refers to a loss discovered in 2008 or 2009 due to a specified fraudulent arrangement involving fraud, embezzlement, or similar crimes. A criminal complaint alleging fraud, embezzlement, or similar crimes, not withdrawn or dismissed, with an admission or affidavit by the person or appointment of a receiver/trustee. The term 'specified fraudulent arrangement' refers to a scheme where a person receives money from investors, claims to generate income for them, provides false income reports, uses new investor funds to pay existing investors, and misappropriates investor funds. The Secretary will issue necessary regulations for this. The amendments made by this section include allowing deductions in calculating net investment loss and applying to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 3 allows for a 6-year net operating loss carryback. Extension of Net Operating Loss Carryback Period to include Qualified fraudulent investment losses. This amendment allows for a longer carryback period for certain losses defined in section 165(m)(2). The amendment extends the net operating loss carryback period for qualified fraudulent investment losses, allowing taxpayers to elect a number of taxable years between 2 and 6 (or 7 in specific cases). Subparagraphs (F) and (H) do not apply to these losses. The amendment extends the net operating loss carryback period for qualified fraudulent investment losses, allowing taxpayers to elect a number of taxable years between 2 and 6 (or 7 in specific cases), based on the age of the taxpayer or spouse and the period of investment in the scheme. A special rule applies for deceased spouses included on joint returns. The qualified fraudulent investment loss can be carried back for a deceased individual, treating it as a loss for both the taxpayer and the deceased individual in the applicable taxable year. Coordination with paragraph (2) is required for applying this rule. The amendments made by this section apply to net operating losses arising in taxable years after December 31, 2007. A transition rule allows for the revocation of certain elections made with respect to net operating losses for taxable years before the enactment of this Act. The amendments allow for the revocation of certain elections made with respect to net operating losses before the enactment of this Act. Any election or application related to such losses must be made or filed before the applicable date, which is 60 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4 amends section 72(t) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow distributions to replace qualified fraudulent investment losses within a 10-year period. SEC. 5 addresses catch-up contributions. Section 219(b)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow catch-up contributions for qualified fraudulent investment losses. Applicable individuals can make additional retirement contributions, increasing the deductible amount for the taxable year. The amendment to Section 219(b)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code allows catch-up contributions for qualified fraudulent investment losses, enabling applicable individuals with such losses to make additional retirement contributions. The amendment allows catch-up contributions for qualified fraudulent investment losses in individual retirement plans, with the amendments applying to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. Extension of limitation for credits and refunds for gifts and bequests of assets with qualified fraudulent investment losses. Extension of limitation for credits and refunds for gifts and bequests of assets with qualified fraudulent investment losses. Amends Section 6511 of the Internal Revenue Code to allow credit or refund for overpayment of taxes related to gifts or bequests involving qualified fraudulent investment losses if taxpayer was unaware of the criminal behavior. Extension of limitation for credits and refunds for gifts and bequests of assets with qualified fraudulent investment losses. The credit or refund must be filed within 6 years after the return related to the credit or overpayment was filed. The value of the gift or bequest for determining the credit or refund should be the greater of the value on the last day of the taxable year in which the fraudulent investment loss was discovered or the amount realized from the disposition of the gift or bequest. The amendments made by this section apply to gifts or bequests made after December 31, 2007.
